And it never crossed the mind of Bellingan and Liebenberg either.  To say to you where are these people based.  Ask you for an address.  Is that right?
I think they didn't think about it also, because they didn't ask me.

And I take it you also didn't, it didn't cross your mind to inform them that the whole group has now moved into one of the addresses in Guguletu that belonged to one of them.  You didn't tell them that either.
I didn't think about it also.
And I presume you also failed to tell them that the whole group had moved to Guguletu.
I told them that we have moved and we were in Guguletu at that time.
And these two experienced policemen didn't ask you where in Guguletu?

The previous time they went to the expense of actually getting you with a white hat on a roof so that they could fly over with a helicopter.  But this time they were so stupid that they didn't even ask you the address.  Is that what you are suggesting.  You said Guguletu and they left it at that.
I told them that one of the houses is the home for one of the boys.  I think the address was already in his possession.  They didn't ask me, I assumed that they knew the address.
Did you tell them which of the boys?
You tell them, one of them, there were several of them staying in Guguletu, not so?  Is that correct?
I can't remember how many of them were originally from Guguletu.	But most of them were staying in Guguletu.
Yes, exactly.  So you tell them, Oh we are staying at one of the addresses of the people in Guguletu.  And they didn't ask you which one.  Is that your evidence, Mr Mbane?
That's my evidence.  They didn't ask me.
And you didn't tell them say, we are staying at Rastaman's address, or whoever's address it was.  Or Chris Piet's address, or whoever's address it was. You didn't bother to tell them that either.
That's correct.  I didn't tell them.

In fact, I may be mistaken but I think when I asked you the question just a while back whether you informed them that you have moved to the address of somebody, you said no you didn't, you didn't think about it.  Now you say you did. 	I may be wrong there, my Lord, but that's my recollection.
My recollection is, my Lord, that he said that I just told them that we had moved to Guguletu.  I think my learned colleague must just be careful not to put words in my client's mouth.
You see, he first of all started off saying he didn't know the addresses, then he changed that to say it was the address of one of the boys, do you recollect that, Mr Moses?
Now, at that stage, your group consisted of nine, call them recruits, and you two, that is you and Maluleka.  Is that right?
When they started there were nine and the others were informers.  They were shot and killed.  The eighth one was a Mozambican guy who came to join us.
Shortly before the attack, your group consisted of nine people, and you and Eric Maluleka.  That was your evidence in chief. 	Is that correct?
We were nine, including myslef and Eric Maluleka.
Your evidence was that there were five of you and subsequently another four joined you.
I don't think so Mr Booyens.  There were seven and there were nine if you included him and Mr Maluleka. Those are my notes.
That was also the evidence in chief.
That's why I am saying Mr Moses.  His evidence in chief.
Mr Chairman, my recollection is that there were four.  Rasta joined and then another four joined them, but in any case that is not too serious because I can get the number nine somewhere else.
I can read if you want to.

No, I accept that that is the Commissioner's note, Mr Chairman.
	So the group, was the group never bigger than seven recruits and you and Eric Maluleka?

With all due respect, that was never his evidence.
His evidence, his evidence in chief was clearly that the group started out with nine and thereafter certain people were killed.  And if my learned friend can recall, that at - when my client testified about the incident itself certain people were dropped, and he was requested to tell the Committee how many at which intervals or stages.  His evidence was clear that at the time of the attack there were seven people and him and Eric included amounted to nine people in total.

If my learned friend listened to my questions, he wouldn't make unnecessary objections.
	I was talking shortly before the attack, how big the group was then.  I knew he said that seven people took part in the attack, Mr Chairman.  I am not talking about the time of the attack.
With all due respect, then my learned friend should be clearer, because if it's shortly, then it's also vague.  If he could given an indication as to what is meant by shortly.
Twenty four hours.  Twenty four hours before the attack, how many members were in your group?
Twelve hours before the attack, how many members were in your group?
Does that include you and Maluleka?
Did you, did this group, excluding you and Maluleka, at any stage consist of nine members?
Yes there were nine before including the informers who wanted to join the group.
So that's why the group was reduced to seven:  the informers were killed?
Now, what was the purpose of burying the two AK47's?  Or hiding them shortly before the attack, in the blankets.
I was trying to reduce the number of arms in the kombi.  So that others can go out and get other arms.  I was not aware that those people were going to be shot.  That was the reason.
Okay, you were unaware that the people were going to be shot.
Anything can happen in that kind of operation.
Now, but why did you want to reduce the number of arms?  You already had enormous fire power in that kombi.  Three AK47's and a few hand guns.  Plus hand grenades.

I wanted that the other people should go to the bush and go and fetch the other weapons, those that were already buried there.  The only people who went away unarmed were those people who were supposed to fetch the arms in the bush.

I don't understand why the arms had to be hidden in the bush.
	You were travelling with three AK47 rifles, and hand guns, in fact there were then at a least a total of seven firearms and hand grenades in that kombi. Why did the two AK's have to be buried?  You said buried in the bush now, so let's assume they were buried in the bush.

Those were the people to alight first from the vehicle.  They were going to fetch the arms.  We were using different points.  They were alighting from the vehicle at different points so then we wanted to reduce the number of arms in the vehicle.
Why was the plan made like that?  That's what I want to know.  I hear what you say, I want to know why.
I was not the only one who was making that decision, we discussed together with the commanders and we reached a decision.  We agreed that we are not going to the same point.
Which commanders did you discuss it with? I thought you were in command.
The three people in charge.  I was the first in charge and another one second in charge and Rasta was the third in charge.
So you were quite enthusiastic about this plan.  Is that right?
That was our decision.  All of us took this decision.
Were you enthusiastic about this plan of ambushing this police kombi?
Can you please repeat the question?  What do you mean about being enthusiastic?

First of all I didn't know that those people were going to be shot because when I went there to show Bellingan that point where we were going to alight, they didn't tell me that they were going to shoot them.  They didn't tell me that.
What did you think they were going to do when people came out of your kombi with AK47's, pistols, hand grenades.  How did you think the police were going to react?
I thought they were going to ambush the kombi and arrest these people.  Not to kill them.

Sorry, is your Lordship finished?
	Why did you think that?
That's what came to my mind.

It was just your own idea.
	But now let's return to the question that you still haven't answered.  Were you as a member of the group enthusiastic about this or did you like the idea of this attack of the police kombi.  That's the answer I have been trying to get out of you.  You haven't been answering that question.
I was happy because I thought they were going to arrest these people and I had been in Cape Town for quite a long time.  I was happy that it was time for me to go back home.

So, did you and Bellingan and the others plan the operation or did only you and Maluleka and Rasta plan the operation.  Or did some of the ideas that you put in, did that come from Bellingan?  Or was it only Rasta and Maluleka?
I last saw Bellingan when I was showing him the place where the whole thing would take place.  It was the last time I saw Bellingan.
I can't remember the day.  But we went there using another kombi that I don't know and I went there to show them the place.
By then your plans had been made:  how the attack was going to take place.  Is that right?
With whom.  Can you please repeat the question.
Mr Mbane, were your plans...the group's plans how to attack the police kombi by then made and finalised?
And did you inform Bellingan exactly what you were going to do?
Did you tell him you were going to bury some firearms in the bush?

Because I only saw Bellingan the day before the incident.  By that time, we hadn't buried the firearms in the bush, because the other people refused to alight from the vehicle carrying arms.  They decided that we should go and bury the firearms in the bush, and Bellingan didn't know anything about that.

No, but you planned to bury the firearms, although they were not buried, your plans were made.  Your plans were finalised.  You told me that.  So why didn't you tell Bellingan you are going to bury some of the firearms in the bush.  And say we'll bury it there, and then he can put up some people to ambush them there.
During our plan, the idea of burying these guns was not decided upon.
So that was a last minute change of plan?
But now, did you make any effort to contact Bellingan on the telephone and tell him listen, they've changed the plan and we are now going to bury some guns, that they can ambush them there?
No, I never tried to do that.
Well, you said you never tried to do it.  You didn't even try.
We decided this at night to put these firearms there and I was with Belletjies that morning.
But I think you told us in your evidence in chief that you could travel as you like.  So why didn't you do that.
Maybe you are not aware. When an operation has already been planned, you don't go in and out in the last minute of the operation.  According to my knowledge, that is not done.  You stay stable.

Now, let us once again return to the question that I still haven't had an answer from.
	Your group planned to attack the police kombi.  That police kombi was going to come through there.  Is that right?
As far as you knew that kombi was still going to be there the next morning.  Is that right?
And if your plan came off, your group were going to fire and shoot at policemen.  Is that right?
That's correct.  There was going to be cross firing.
And your group might kill those policemen.  Is that right?

You did nothing at all to try and safeguard those other policemen by dropping the people off at the wrong points or something.
	As far as you were concerned, you were setting them up for a real ambush where they could kill the policemen.  Is that right?
That is why I went to tell Liebenberg and Belletjies well before time.
And apart from the hiding of the firearms, did you give them your full plan how you were going to ambush the people?
As I have already said, your honour we planned this all of us and during the last minutes, that's when we took the decision to go and bury the other stuff at night and we rode off after doing that.

So when was the final plan how your group was going to ambush the police kombi made?
	Was that only made on the Sunday night?
Was it then decided that you would drop people at various points.  They would get up at various points, etc.
Now, did you drop some of the...the police kombi that you were supposed to ambush was coming across the bridge over the N2.  Is that correct?
Now, did you drop off some of your men there? Because you travelled in the direction of the bridge I think...
Those were the ones with the pistols.  Is that correct?
Was this also something that you decided upon on Sunday night?
Everything was finalised on Sunday night.
So your earlier statement that the plans for the ambush were finalised before you spoke to Bellingan the previous days was incorrect.
I met Bellingan on Sunday, but the final arrangements were made on Sunday night and that is when we decided on a few changes and I didn't have sufficient time to go and notify Bellingan.
So Bellingan didn't know at all what your plan was.  Nobody in the police knew what your plan was. They knew there was going to be an attack, but they had not details of it.  Is that right?
I told you honour that I told Bellingan and Belletjies and I showed them the spot where everything was supposed to take place.  So obviously they were aware of the attack.
Now the three of you in the vehicle with the AK47's.  What were you going to do?
Everybody was going to get off and occupy their specified positions.
Yes, including us.	But we knew that we were to be arrested.
But, if the arrest didn't come off were you going to attack that police kombi?
That I don't know.  The only thing I knew was that these people were around because when we approached I saw a white kombi and I identified it.  I knew it.

You see my problem with your statement here is simply the following.
	That you knew you were going to be arrested.  But people were dropped in various points.  How were the police to know who to arrest?

They have been lying in a wait a long time.  They knew the time that it was going to happen between 7:00 and a quarter past.  They were deployed well on time because when I went past I saw the kombi parked there.
	And that's when I suspected that they must be all over the place.

So, you saw a kombi parked there.
	Was that the only indication you saw of police presence?
That's right.  Because I know that kombi.  It's ours.

You didn't know whether there were any policemen at the point, higher up near the bridge over the N2 where you dropped the men with the handguns.
	Is that right?
The only thing I knew is that they might be deployed all over the area.  I expect that.
You expected that.  You weren't told that they would be deployed all over the area.

I knew that it was going to be like that.
	I saw our kombi there and I just told myself that they must be all over the place.
Were you not told to try and keep these people in the kombi and ride into the crossing and that they would overwhelm you there and the rest of the people?
Yes, they told me that.  But when decisions were taken at the last minute, what was I expected to do?

So Bellingan's instructions to you were keep the whole group in the kombi, we want to arrest them there while everybody is in the kombi before a fire fight starts.  That's what he wanted.  You couldn't control it because the situation got out of hand.  Is that what you are saying?
The last minute arrangements of hiding the firearms were done by the whole group and they knew the area more than me and they decided on the dropping points as well.

Mr Mbane, just listen to my question.
	Bellingan instructed you that you must try and keep all these people in the kombi into the intersection so that they can be arrested there.  That's what he wanted you to do.  Is that right?  Let's take it bit by bit.
He never mentioned any arrests.  I don't remember that.  He just said...did he say that I must keep them in the kombi so that he can arrest them?
Well, did he tell you to try and keep them all in the kombi until you were in the intersection?

I must say I don't know how the interpretation is, but at first I thought my learned colleague was making a statement, was putting it as a statement of fact to the witness.  Those were Bellingan's instructions.
	Now it seems that it was thereafter transformed into a question.  I have heard now out of the translation that the witness has now even picked that up also and asked him whether that was in fact a statement or a question.
	Perhaps he could just be clear as to whether those were his instructions, and whether those instructions were given as a fact.  For clarity's sake.
Perhaps my learned friend shouldn't try and take over my cross examination my Lord.
If the cross examination is clear, my Lord.  If it's not clear, it's my legal duty to try to protect the witness.
Did Bellingan tell you that you must try to keep the people in the kombi.  All of them.?

He said so.  He said you must try.  He did not instruct me.  He said I must try.  There's a difference between saying "try".  He did not instruct me.  I don't know whether that will fulfil your answer.

No, that's fine.  Because that's exactly what Bellingan said.  He said that he said you must try and keep the people together.
	But you couldn't do it.  You had a practical problem with that.  Is that what you are saying?
Now, at the scene, you off loaded Maluleka and who first?  The two that were supposed to go and pick up the AK's.
And one other boy, I don't remember his name.
How far from the spot where the AK's were kept did you drop them off?
It might have been 250 metres away.
Why drop them so far from the weapons?
That was according to the plan.
But that's illogical.  You were one of the commanders of this operation. Why drop them so far?
It is because you were not there during our planning session.  I am telling you that's the decision that we took there.  I hope that suffices.
It doesn't.  It's illogical.  Why was it planned that way?
We decided on that as a group.
That you are going to let them walk 250 paces to go and pick up their arms when they were going to ambush the police kombi.
It's by no means clear, Mr Booyens, whether this 250 yards was 250 yards along the road or 250 yards into the bush.

Point taken my Lord.  I'll clear that up.
	The place where the firearms were buried, was it next to the road?

It was in the bush.  And they were going to walk into the bush and the spot we were going to attack was 250 metres away from that point.
	If you say that I dropped them far, where would you suggest I drop them?
How far was the point where the arms were buried from the road?
I don't remember clearly.  Maybe if I can see the area, I can remember.  I know now that it's built up.
Was it close to the road, that's all I want to know.
It was right inside the bush and they had to use the shortest route, because they knew that area.  That is the first group, they knew where to find them.
Okay.  You thereafter proceeded and dropped the next group of people in the direction of the bridge and you made a u-turn at the bridge.  Is that correct.

I dropped the other three.  When you say on the bridge, I am pretty confused.  I say I dropped the first lot and then I dropped the other three 100 metres away and then I dropped another one and the remaining three went to make a u-turn and when we came around there was already firing.
Okay.  The first sound you heard was the sound like the explosion of a hand grenade.  Is that correct?
Yes, it sounded like a grenade explosion.
Did you then proceed into the intersection?
No, I went on the pavement and I jumped out the car and when I attempted to run I heard some shots and laid flat on my tummy.
No, but did you hit the pavement in the intersection, in the crossing or close to the crossing?
And you then heard gun fire?
You took cover.  Is that right?
I said to you I hit the pavement and jumped out the vehicle.
Okay, how far from the kombi?
It was hardly 10 metres from the kombi, 7 to 10 metres away from the kombi it might have been.
No right.  At that stage there were still two people inside the kombi.  Is that right?

I jumped off first, then Rasta followed because I was driving and the one who was inside because he was sitting in the middle and didn't have enough chance to jump off because there was too much firing.
And  you say this man was shot by Bellingan.  Or you heard a shot in the kombi.

As I was taking cover because I was near the car and I know a fire ringing.  I heard this fire, the shot ringing in the car.  As I was trying to run I heard some shots ringing and I took cover, but I heard Belletjies saying: "Don't shoot the tall man.  He is one of us".  I am not sure whether you understand Afrikaans.  This is what he said.
	And then I heard a fire ringing in the car, and I saw Belletjies grabbing this man and then he hit him with a shot.  I was watching it when I ran away.

Let's just deal first with the shooting inside the kombi.
	Who fired the shot that you heard inside the kombi?
It was Belletjies.  Because he had just called out don't shoot the tall man.  He is the one who shot inside the vehicle.
So he first shouted don't shoot the tall man and then he fired a shot into the kombi.

He shouted first don't shoot the tall man and then I heard a fire, a shot ringing in the car.  Whether he shot the man or not, I am not sure but the shot went off in the car.  And then he dragged him out of the vehicle and he landed on the ground.  He landed on his side.
And then he fired a shot again?  Bellingan?
Yes, he fired again.  This person was lying on the ground.  I could see 7 to 10 metres away.
How many shots did he fire while this person was on the ground?
I heard one shot in the vehicle, I don't know whether he hit him or not.  He dragged him outside and threw him on the ground, but outside I heard about 2 shots, because I was very near.
So there must have been three AK47's left in the kombi.  Not so?
Did all three of you get out without your AK's?
I am not sure.  There was quite a confusion.  Whether he had his AK rifle, I am not sure.  But the other gentleman didn't have his rifle with.  My AK they found inside the vehicle.

Well, for you information they didn't find it inside the vehicle.  There wasn't, according to the police report....there was a total of only 3 AK47's were found there and not five, and on your description there should have been five.
There were supposed to be five.  Belletjies and them know exactly where they are.  There are supposed to be five.  They know where the rest are.

The two AK's in the blanket were found and one was found with Chris Piet and he was not in the immediate vicinity of the kombi.  There is no...on what this Committee has been told and on what the inquest has been told there is a total of three AK's found.
	You don't know where the other two are.  You say there must have been five.  There must have been two in the kombi, not so?  You didn't take yours.  The man that you say was shot by Bellingan didn't take his, so there must have been two AK's in the kombi.

All I know is that we had five AK rifles.  Four of them, I took them inside the kombi.  One AK we got from Rasta, the Makarov, Tokarev and two hand grenades.  Then if that didn't appear during the inquest, that's not my business.  If they have done their cover-ups, I don't know anything about that and that is not my business.
Did you say there were four AK's in the kombi?
Your honour, we had three AK's in the kombi, and then we had...all of them made up five AK's.

I must add, my Lord, that I have heard that the interpreter said two when he testified in Xhosa.  She translated it as two.  But when he himself testified in English he referred to three in the kombi.  That is how I understood it, just to clear that up.
Did you have a hand gun with you?
Did you keep that with you?
Yes, I kept it with me.
Even when you ran away you kept it with you.  Is that right?
And how did you get to Koeberg?
I ran to one of the houses, they gave me some clothes to change so that I could disguise.  They took me to Yamile's place.  From there they took me to the bus.  From there I took a bus to Koeberg.
Were there buses running right to Koeberg at that stage?
There were buses to Koeberg at the time.
The - now apart from the man close to the kombi that you say was shot by Mr Bellingan, did you see anybody else being shot?

When I was running away, just a distance from the kombi, there were firing just across the road.  I saw Rastaman falling, and I didn't see they were shooting, I just saw him falling and he stood up again.  Then I ran away because I was also afraid of the gunshots.
When Rasta was running, did he have his AK with him?
He had his AK rifle.  Because I saw him falling and he stood up again and he fell again and he stood up again with his rifle.  He was not far from my direction.  There was just a tar road in between.
As he was falling, I'm not sure, I can't say he was shooting, because he fell and stood up again and fell again and stood up.  I am not sure if he was actually firing.
Were you subsequently asked to identify the bodies?
I did not identify the bodies.  All I saw was the video the following day.
Didn't you go to the morgue?  The mortuary.
Do you know whether Eric went to the mortuary?
Were you shown the video and asked to ID the people?
Some of them were badly injured, their bodies were bullet riddled, although I could identify some of them.
So, are you saying that you yourself never identified the bodies, nor all of them on the video.  Is that correct?
I couldn't identify all of them on the video.
All seven of the people that were killed were members of your group.  Is that right?

I recently saw a television interview with a man who claimed he was also there, and if necessary we are endeavouring to get that video, but he actually got away from that attack.  Were there only seven of them or were there more?
A man, he wasn't identified, who claimed that he was also there, but he escaped the trap, he wasn't killed.
All I know is that there were nine of us.  I don't know of anybody who escaped.
Can you perhaps insofar as it may be necessary to put to you what the police evidence is.  You are not in a position to dispute that members of  group attacked the police first.  Is that correct?
Those who were with me in the kombi, no one attacked the police.  I won't know whether when they were outside if somebody shot at the police or not.

The police evidence was that the first thing that happened is that one of the people threw a hand grenade at a police car.  You are not in a position to dispute that.  You actually heard a hand grenade.  Is that right?
All I am saying is that who threw the grenade, I don't know.  Even the police have hand grenades.

Mr Mbane, you have obviously completely changed sides again politically.  Is that correct?  Are you now a loyal and good supporter of the ANC again?  You don't support the erstwhile forces that you were associated with?  Is that correct?
My Lords, are the political convictions at this point..does it bear any relevance?
It may affect his credibility, mighten it?
You were an ex-ANC member, you stayed loyal to them.  Are you now again a full and loyal member and supporter of the ANC?  Is that right?
I don't belong to any political organisation.  I lead my life now.
Very well.  Just to sum up the police evidence will be that someone threw a hand grenade, people shot at a police car, the police shot back and in the fire fight people were killed.
I don't have any knowledge about that.
Furthermore, nobody shot at anybody inside the vehicle.  Bellingan specifically didn't shoot at anybody inside the vehicle.  He shot at a person who was outside the vehicle.
I deny that because I was just 7 to 10 metres from Bellingan.  It's not what I heard people saying.  I was there.
Did you see Bellingan shoot inside the vehicle?
I told you before, I am not sure whether you want me to repeat that?
Tell me again.  Did you see him shoot.  Yes or no.
I saw him shooting, I told you before.
Where was he standing at that stage, when he fired the shot into the vehicle?

I heard a gunshot inside the kombi.  He pulled this person out of the kombi.  I am not sure whether he was actually shooting at this person while he was lying flat, but he shot this person and I saw him shooting this person because I was just 7 to 10 metres away from him.
The question is where was Bellingan when you fired the shot into the kombi.
Are you saying in relation to the kombi, Mr Booyens?

Yes, your Lordship.  I am just trying to find out was Bellingan inside the kombi when he fired the shot.  Or was he standing outside the kombi shooting into the kombi, that's what I am trying to find out from the witness.  Answer the question please.

I told you that Bellingan, there was a person in the kombi, I heard a gunshot and he dragged this person out of the kombi and the person fell down.  I didn't see any blood.  When I was closer to him, I saw him shooting this person outside the kombi.  He stood there and I heard a gunshot and he dragged this person out of the car.  It's when this person fell down and that's when I saw Bellingan shooting.  I am not sure whether you are satisfied by that.

No I am not.  Because you told us that he fired inside the kombi, in fact repeated that statement I don't know how many times.
	Now I want to know how do you know he fired inside the kombi?

I didn't say that.  I said I heard a gunshot inside the kombi.  From there I saw Bellingan dragging a person out of the kombi and this person fell and he shot this person.  Yes, I heard a gunfire inside the kombi, but I didn't see him shooting the person.  I only saw him pulling this person out of the car and the person fell and he shot that person.  I am not sure if you are satisfied.
How do you know if this shot was fired inside the kombi?
As I am telling you Sir, I was just 7 to 10 metres from the car.  I  know a gunshot, I know how it sounds.
Yes, but why couldn't it have been right next to the kombi?  On the outside.
I heard the gunshot inside the kombi, not outside the kombi.
Are you seriously suggesting that you could hear whether the gun was being fired inside the kombi, or whether it was being fired next to the kombi?

I was closer to the kombi and I could hear the gunshot inside the kombi and this person was dragged out of the kombi and I saw when he was shot at close range.  I don't know what is it that you want me to say.
What I want to know is how you can say that the shot was fired inside the kombi.  Did it sound differently, or why do you say it.  Why could the shot not have been fired right next to the kombi?

The gunshot was right inside the kombi.  I don't know how to explain this.  Because I was just next to this kombi and I saw him dragging the person, I didn't even know who was being shot inside the kombi.
So there must have been a bullet hole at least in the kombi.  Unless he was firing blanks?
I don't have any knowledge about that.
Well you are adamant that he was shooting inside the kombi.  Then one would expect at least a bullet hole inside the kombi.  Not so?
It depends.  There could be a bullet, but if the bullet shot a person, there wouldn't be any bullet in the kombi.
Yes, then there would be blood in the kombi.  Not so?  Do you know where Bellingan was when he fired this shot, or don't you?
